title: How to Cut Glass for Crafts

methods.name: Scoring Mosaic Tiles with a Glass Cutter

steps.headline: Put on safety glasses and gloves before you start.
steps.description: Glass can easily break or shatter, so protect your hands and eyes from any stray shards. Use cut-resistant gloves meant for glass-cutting so you can still handle your pieces easily without hurting yourself. Make sure to always wear the safety glasses and gloves while you’re working. You can buy cut-resistant gloves from hardware or craft supply stores.

steps.headline: Draw the shape you want to cut on your piece of glass.
steps.description: Use a fine-point marker to draw the line for your cut. If you want your line to be straight, use a ruler or another straightedge. Don’t draw the line too thick, or else the marker will be visible after you make your cut. If you don’t want to draw directly on the glass, put a piece of paper with the shape you want to draw underneath the glass so you can trace it with the glass cutter.

steps.headline: Set the wheel of a glass cutter against the smooth side of the glass.
steps.description: Glass cutters have a notched end with a small scoring wheel on the tip. Make sure the piece of glass you’re cutting is on a flat surface so you can easily make your cut. Hold the glass cutter so your index and middle fingers are on top of it, and so the wheel points down. Press the wheel onto the glass where you plan on making your cut. Look for glass cutters at craft supply stores or online. If your glass is smooth on both sides, it doesn’t matter which side you make your cut on.

steps.headline: Drag the glass cutter along the line that you want to cut.
steps.description: Apply a small amount of pressure to the glass cutter so it etches into the surface of the glass. Pull the glass cutter toward you along the outline you drew to leave a score mark on the glass. Keep dragging the glass cutter until you reach the edge of the glass to complete your cut. The glass cutter will only cut part way through the glass to make it easier to break. Don’t try to force the cutter completely through the glass, or else it may shatter or break in a different place. Only make 1 cut at a time so it’s easier to break apart later on.Tip: If you want the score to be perfectly straight, guide the glass cutter with a straightedge so the line isn’t crooked.

steps.headline: Flip the piece of glass over so the cut is face-down.
steps.description: Once you make a score line on one side of the glass, turn it over so the clean side is face-up. If you have trouble picking the piece of glass off of your table, slide an index card underneath it and pull the corner of the card up to get a better grip.

steps.headline: Grip the edge of the glass with a pair of pliers.
steps.description: Hold the pliers in your dominant hand and position them so they’re halfway along the length of your cut. Open the pliers and gently squeeze the handles together to grip the edge of the glass. Make sure the pliers don’t cover any part of your cut or else it won’t make a clean edge when you break it. If you’re worried about the pliers scratching your piece of glass, wrap the ends with masking tape.

steps.headline: Push down on the glass to break it along the cut.
steps.description: Place your nondominant hand on the side of the score line that’s opposite from the pliers. Hold the pliers steady and gently push down on the glass with your nondominant hand. The glass will break along the line and leave a smooth edge. If the piece of glass doesn’t break along the score line, then flip it over and try using the glass cutter again to make the cut slightly deeper.

steps.headline: Clean any paper or adhesive off of a glass bottle.
steps.description: Peel any labels or paper off of the bottle’s surface as much as you can so you don’t need to cut through them. If there is any stuck-on adhesive, wipe the bottle with a cleaning rag and adhesive remover. Continue wiping the bottle until it’s completely clean. If you’re cutting your bottle above or below the label, you don’t need to remove the paper or adhesive if you don’t want to.

steps.headline: Set the bottle on top of the rollers on a bottle cutter.
steps.description: Set up the bottle cutter on a flat surface so the 2-3 rollers are face-up. Look for the small metal scoring wheel on the side of the bottle cutter, and set the bottle on top of the cutter so the wheel lines up with the line you want to cut. Make sure the bottle touches at least 2 of the rollers so it can spin easily. You can buy a bottle cutter from a craft store or online.

steps.headline: Adjust the scoring blade so it touches the bottle.
steps.description: If the scoring wheel doesn’t touch the bottle, loosen the screw holding it in place with either a screwdriver or a hex wrench. Position the scoring wheel so it touches the bottle so it can cut the glass. Once the wheel is in position, tighten it again so it doesn’t fall out of place. The tool you need to adjust the scoring wheel depends on the bottle cutter you’re using.

steps.headline: Rotate the bottle on the rollers to make a score line.
steps.description: Press down gently on the bottle so the scoring wheel etches into the glass. Slowly rotate the bottle on the rollers while applying pressure so the score line goes completely around the glass. Complete 2 full rotations around the bottle to ensure that the score is deep enough for the bottle to break easily. Don’t press too hard on the bottle or else you might shatter it.

steps.headline: Pour hot water over the line you scored on the bottle.
steps.description: Heat water on your stove or in the microwave until it’s about 180–200 °F (82–93 °C). Hold the bottle over your sink so you can easily pour the water onto the score line. Slowly pour the water onto the end of the bottle with the score line, and rotate it so the glass heats up evenly. If the bottle gets too hot to hold, wear an oven mitt so you don’t burn yourself.

steps.headline: Dip the bottle in ice water to break it along the score line.
steps.description: As soon as you’re finished pouring the hot water on the bottle, dip it into a bowl filled with ice water. The sudden temperature change will cause the bottle to break into 2 pieces along the score line. Once the bottle breaks, pull it out of the water and dry it off with a towel. If the bottle doesn’t break immediately, then repeat pouring hot water and dipping it in cold water until it does.

steps.headline: Sand any rough edges with 220-grit sandpaper.
steps.description: If the bottle has jagged edges, apply a firm amount of pressure to the glass with 220-grit sandpaper to smooth it out. Continue working around the edge of the bottle until it’s smooth to the touch and there aren’t any shards that could hurt you. If the edges of the bottle are very uneven, it may be difficult to sand the bottle to the shape you want. Try cutting another bottle instead since it’s easier.Tip: Wet the piece of sandpaper if it’s difficult to smooth out the rough edges.

steps.headline: Cut a length of yarn that can wrap around the bottle 3-4 times.
steps.description: Use a fabric or acrylic piece of yarn since they are the most absorbent and work the best. Wrap the end of the yarn around the bottle along the line you want to cut 3-4 times to find the length you need. Unwind the yarn and use a pair of scissors to cut it. You can also use twine if you don’t have any yarn. Don’t use thread or string since it’s too thin to cut through the glass.

steps.headline: Soak the yarn in acetone nail polish remover.
steps.description: Fill a small bowl with acetone nail polish remover and dip the piece of yarn into it. Make sure the yarn is completely saturated with the acetone, or else you won’t be able to cut the bottle well. Pull the yarn out from the acetone and shake any excess off of the surface. You can buy acetone nail polish remover from convenience stores.

steps.headline: Wrap the yarn around the bottle where you want to cut it.
steps.description: Take the acetone-soaked yarn and rewrap it around the bottle it the place you measured it. Once you loop it around the bottle the third or fourth time, tuck the end of the yarn underneath the loops to hold it in place. Push the loops as close together as you can to make the cut more precise.Tip: If the yarn still doesn’t stay in place, cut a new piece of yarn that’s 2–3 inches (5.1–7.6 cm) longer so you can tie a knot.

steps.headline: Light the yarn on fire with a lighter.
steps.description: Hold the bottle over your sink so you don’t risk burning anything else. Hold the lighter underneath your bottle and light the yarn so it catches on fire. Rotate the bottle so the flame spreads evenly around the yarn wrapped onto the bottle. The fire will burn the acetone and heat the yarn and bottle so it’s easier to break. Be very careful while working with an open flame so you don’t burn yourself.

steps.headline: Submerge the bottle in ice water immediately after the yarn goes out.
steps.description: After about 30 seconds or when the flame on the yarn goes out, dip the bottle completely in a bowl full of ice water. The sudden change in temperature will cause the bottle to break where you wrapped it with yarn. Once the bottle breaks apart, pull it out of the water and let it dry. Be careful with the bottle after it breaks since the edges might be sharp. If the bottle doesn’t break after the first time, soak another piece of yarn in acetone and repeat the process.

steps.headline: Sand the broken edges with 220-grit sandpaper to remove any rough edges.
steps.description: Apply a gentle amount of pressure to the sandpaper around the edges of the bottle to smooth it out. Rotate the bottle while you sand it so you can get an even finish completely around the break. Keep working around the edge until there aren’t any shards left on the bottle. If the edges are very uneven, you may not be able to sand them smooth.
